Notice in the lower right corner of the instructions there is an I with arrow pointing to a WWW for I assume information. Does this mean, if you need help search the web? A web might be helpful. On plus side, the printer works fine, with good print quality. I assume that I will get the wireless part working at some point.

title: Why do printer manufacturers assume everyone employs an IT department?
body: Printers are supposed to be patient servants who sit idle, but snap to attention when you need them. They do seem too if you have a wired connection. Adding Wifi seems to reduce the printer's IQ by half. Unless you have your own IT department or a 12 year old close by to rescue you. Now that that's out of the way, here are my impressions of this Lexmark B3340 so far. I was looking for a replacement for my Cannon, that was most of all intuitive and whose Wifi just plain worked every time. Unboxing seemed promising but suspect since documentation included one sheet of printed media and a DVD. The single sheet of "instructions" contained no words, just a few cave wall drawings with a helpful bent page indicator in the lower right hand corner indicating the need to turn the page over to continue. Good thing, I never would have noticed it was printed on both sides! Step 12 indicates you need to turn the printer on. The final step indicates you insert the DVD into your laptop. If only laptops still had DVD readers. In my Apple world those are barely even remembered. So there we both sat in awkward silence.There is a tiny, single line display so I decided to break the ice and start pushing the few buttons there. It asked if I wanted to set it up using an app. Yes please. I downloaded the only Lexmark app I could find onto my phone, but that proved to be a dead end. I used my iMac to try to locate drivers for the B3340 and finally wading through microscopic online print and charts seemed to find what I needed so clicked the hyperlink for Mac. Nothing downloaded. I connected the printer to my desktop to see if that might make a love connection. I thankfully had the correct cable. Would have been nice if Lexmark had included one but maybe no one does that any more. Though others seem to make even a tiny effort to give you a modicum of direction. I opened my Printer preference tab, and by golly, it had recognized the new printer. Clicking on some options seemed promising but still no directions. I went back to that single line display and started clicking through and eventually found an option to connect to Wifi. It found my network thankfully and asked for my password. I hoped there might be a more handy input method. But no, you need to go through small a, capital A, small b capital B, etc. for each part of your password. Mine dutifully is 10 characters long so it was a lot of tapping. Eventually all was set up, and I directed the computer to print a page and selected the Lexmark. Thankfully it instantly printed the page, though the quality seemed a little light and non-crisp. Imagining there were internal adjustments I went back to single line display, but nothing there. In the mean time the printer went into sleep mode. I opened the Printer choices but nothing helpful there. After pushing the back arrow on the printer it said it was "ready" and fully awake. Thats when, in the Printer section under the "general" tab, there was a tiny box that said it would take you to the printer web site. I bit, and although it's not obvious at all, there are nests of settings that will adjust your printer, including print quality and darkness level. I made the adjustments, printed another page and the page was beautiful. I was interrupted but returned to make sure all was in order, tried to print another page but nothing. It said it couldn't find the printer. Ten minutes later, the page printed.Over all, this seems to be a solid relatively compact printer. It says it's made out of steel though the exterior seems like hard plastic. The single line of display gives basic information only after lots of clicking and little intuitive guidance. Once all is set up to the settings of your choice, it seems promising. I cancelled sleep mode but it still seems to doze off and not print wirelessly on command. I'll keep tinkering. In conclusion, unit build seems solid, compact and unencumbered by buttons and blinking lights. Five stars there. As for helpful setup directions or any guidance I would give it zero stars if possible. I believe this will prove to be a solid, reliable printer. As long as I don't need to wake it up by physically pushing a button on the controls, and the wifi proves reliable, I should be happy. If you're reading Lexmark, can't you simply include a second piece of printed instructions that gives a buyer even a scrap of guidance? At least for customers who exist in the Apple universe, or with Windows laptops that lack DVD access?

title: Great monochrome laser for the home/small office
body: This is a compact, somewhat lightweight black & white laser printer. No scanner, fax, or copier. But as a printer it is excellent. Print speeds are fast at just about 1.5 seconds per page and the built-in duplexer is great. The instructions are just pictures, which can be a bit confusing, but once you have the printer out of the box they make more sense. This only comes with a power cable so if you're going to connect directly to a computer you will need a printer cable (that funky cable with a squarish connector). Because of all our devices we went with the wireless option for connectivity. The 2-line monochrome screen is used to set it up (date, time, time zone, connect to network). Again, no instructions. If you've set up a printer before this is not terrible, but a user manual would have made it much better. Do note that your network has to be 2G and not 5G. It does come with a CD but I prefer to download the latest from the manufacturer's website. This is a 100MB download for the full package. The Lexmark app installed fine on my Android tablet (Samsung) and I was able to print from there as well. This is a simple but very nice B&W laser that works well for any home office or even a small business office.

title: Great Desktop Laser Printer!
body: Needed a desktop printer for my office. I often print reports, emails, etc and don't want to go to the larger network printer down the hall to retrieve them. A local desktop printer is the perfect solution and this was a great choice!What I Like:Lexmark brand has a great reputation for making quality printers. I expect to get several years of use from this unit.Print quality is excellent - as is expected from a laser printer.Print speed is also very good - large reports print nearly as quickly as the huge printer down the hall!Refill toner cartridge is reasonably priced - more so than toner for color printers.Can connect via wireless by connecting to local wifi network or directly via a USB or ethernet cable - nice to have several options - I opted for a direct cable connection from my PC.Really nice printer and very happy with it - highly recommend!

title: A great little printer!
body: This wireless laser printer produces 2 sided printing and can be used with a mobile device. The paper feed has a 100 page capacity and the printer is capable of producing up to 40 copies per minute. This unit is very sturdily constructed and works beautifully! It's a nice, compact size weighing only 23 pounds that will fit easily into any office where space is limited and it needs only a very minimal amount of maintenance compared to many other brand models. It has Wi-Fi , USB and Ethernet connectivity capabilities. This printer is a quality investment for any small business or home office. I recommend it!

title: Disposable
body: I didn't do my research before ordering this printer. In this day and age, I didn't really think that I would have to because usually you can find aftermarket toner cartridges on the cheap, but I'm having trouble finding toner cartridges for the Lexmark B2338adw Monochrome Laser Printer other than the $87 Lexmark return cartridge here on Amazon.If you do the math, that means that the printer is worth about $20 and the toner is worth $90! To be fair, the starter toner is a specially loaded toner cartridge with far less toner than the regular one, so it could be argued that the printer is $50 - maybe. But if you think about it, you could easily make a case for just ordering a new printer every time the toner runs out, rather than using the same printer and ordering new toner each time.I feel like this is deceiving. It would be far more honest to sell the printer with a REAL CARTRIDGE that is loaded full and charge the full price - that way you would know what it was going to cost you in real world dollars and perhaps more importantly, you could comparison shop and see what it actually costs compared to other printers. The REAL price of this printer is the price of the printer PLUS a toner cartridge which is closer to $200 than $100.Otherwise, this looks like a decent laser printer that will handle heavy printing loads and is easy to set up with Windows or Mac. But I am so put off by the marketing and price of the cartridges that I don't know if I trust the company with my business.Before you school me on the fact that all printer companies do this, I am aware that it is a common practice - but I have never seen it quite so blatant or so costly. Usually you can bypass the printer company's overpriced toner or ink and save money. But for whatever reason, there appear to be no choices except Lexmark's expensive toner. I'd shop around and find a printer that isn't going to cost quite so much in consumables as time goes on.

title: Perfect for home use and multiple options for printing wirelessly
body: This Lexmark B2338adw Print Only Monochrome Laser Printer is perfect for home use and has multiple options for printing from your computer, your phone or your tablet.Understand that this is a laser printer. Laser printers print very differently from ink jet printers. It uses powdered toner which is attracts to the paper via an electric charge. A fuser permanently fuses the toner to the paper. Hence, there are no print heads or liquid ink. This process makes a laser printer and attractive choice for people who do not print large amounts or frequently as there are no print heads to get clogged or ink to dry up.Although there are color laser printers, this is a monochrome printer so only one toner cartridge, which is easy to install and replace and all of the toner is available for use as laser printers don't need priming, as ink jet printers do. Laser printers also produce incredibly crisp prints.One thing to note is that the toner cartridge for this printer is currently ~$90. Before you gasp, realize that the toner cartridge is rated for about 3,000 pages. There is a greater initial outlay for a laser printer toner cartridge but you don't generally replace them as often as ink jet cartridges. This printer comes with a starter toner cartridge installed, which is rated for about 1,500 pages.You can use this printer directly connected to your computer via a USB printer cable (NOT included), over your wifi network or as a wired network printer via an ethernet cable (NOT included.) Lexmark has a free app called the Lexmark Mobile Assistant to help you set the printer up. I have an android phone and I downloaded the app but for some reason, it couldn't find the printer. I didn't try for long because you can actually set it up using the control panel on the printer. You just need to know the name of your wifi network and the password. The printer connected instantly to my wifi network.Next, I tried installing the software on the included CD but again, ran into some issues with the software not finding the printer. I skipped that and went into my Windows Control Panel, selected Hardware and Sound, and then selected Advanced Printer Setup. It found the printer and when I selected it, Windows automatically installed the drivers for the printer and prompted me to print a test page to ensure it was working properly. The test page printed instantly and perfectly.If you have a Chromebook, you won't be able to connect the printer to your computer via a USB printer cable. Instead, you will use Google Cloud Print, which you will need to set up. You can also print wirelessly via Apple AirPrint, Mopris Print Service and Lexmark Mobile Print so you have a lot of options for printing from your phone or tablet.This is a printer only. It doesn't scan or copy as it is not an all-in-one printer. It does, however, have auto duplexing, which is automatic, double sided printing. It has a 250 sheet paper tray and a multi-purpose feeder for envelopes and specialty papers. It prints very quickly - even double sided pages. Print quality is excellent.My only complaint is that, like many printers these days, there is no printed user manual included. You can download it from the Lexmark website, though. While you are there, note that there is a firmware update available for this printer. You'll need to download the update and follow the directions carefully to install the update. Firmware updates are important and shouldn't be ignored so take time to do this.

title: High quality printer with full AirPrint support for the Mac and iPhone
body: This is an excellent printer for Mac users, especially if you have in iPhone. There is a two page cartoon showing how to unpack it, and the only confusing thing is that there is both a toner cartridge and an imaging unit into which the toner cartridge fits. When the printer arrives, both items are installed but with packing tape and pads surrounding them and they must be removed. The cartoons are not all that helpful in figuring out what to remove, but it is fairly obvious when you have the item in your hand. Just make sure all the tape and foam padding are removed and replace the imaging unit first, and then put the toner cartridge in next.The software setup is trivial if you have an iPhone. Download the Lexmark Mobile Print app from the app store and follow the prompts. I was done in less than a minute and the printer was then available via air print on all the other mac computers and phones in the house. The WIFI on this printer is highly stable.The reason I gave this only four stars is that Lexmark charges too much for its toner cartridges. Indeed, the toner cartridge for this printer costs more than the printer! Furthermore, the printer comes with a starter toner cartridge that will only last a few months at most. So my strong recommendation is to buy the printer + toner package. It will save you about $20.That complaint noted, this is an outstanding and reliable printer. For mac users it is especially nice because AirPrint has been fully implemented, which is not the case for many printers I have bought which claim to support it, but have only a partial implementation.

title: Lexmark B2338 Print Only Monochrome Duplex Laser Printer
body: I switched to laser printers because I rarely print in color or make copies and the constant expense of color cartridges that were little used but dried-out anyway seemed a wasteful use of limited resources. This printer has a USB and an Ethernet port so it can be connected wirelessly or through a wired network or a computer.The printer creates crisp clean output and preferences regarding resolution, darkness, brightness, etc. can be selected by the user. This device arrives with a toner cartridge that is stated to print 1500 copies which is half the regular cartridge (B231000) capacity of 3000 copies. If interested, there is also a high-yield cartridge available.Printing can be accomplished through any device connected to the printer’s network. To use a mobile device, like a smartphone or tablet, the Lexmark Print app must be loaded. In Windows 10 no app is needed– just set up like any other printer. Details of my experience configuring the printer follow but in summary so far the printer is fast, the print quality is excellent and it works reliably whether printing from my wireless phone and laptop as well as my wired desktop PC.Following the two page visual instructions included in the box, I unpacked the printer and plugged in the power cord. The 2 by 1/2 inch illuminated display window stated—setup using the mobile app. At the Apple app store I installed the Lexmark Mobile Assistant.The app instructed I should go to Settings on iPhone, find printer name shown on the printer display and connect to my local WiFi network using my network passphrase. Then I returned to the app and followed the remaining steps. If not planning to connect to WiFi, connect to a wired network using the Ethernet port or connect directly with a USB cable. These cables are not included.At this point it is ready to print wirelessly. On my desktop the printer was immediately recognized by Windows 10 so I did not load the included software disc. As mentioned above to print with my smartphone I loaded the Lexmark Print app. Once the mobile app is loaded the printer appears in the Sharing option for all apps that support printing.No printed manual is included but PDFs for a Quick Start Guide along with a very detailed User Manual are available at the company website along with information about firmware updates, FAQs, etc.If security is a concern a Pin number can be established. In the configuration settings a pin number may be created that applies to all jobs or individually at print time. In either case there is no output until the user types in the pin number at the printer console. Printing can be restricted to network users and/or local accounts.Also the user can erase (sanitize) printer memory (automatically saved image) to avoid sensitive documents being reprinted without authorization. This is a complex feature detailed in the user manual. Decent features at this price point.

title: Printer is making a grinding noise
body: The printer makes a grinding noise right after printing. Have checked as per instructions on Lexmark's site but I don't see any obstructions of any type. Been through their entire checklist. I may just want to get this one replaced. After checking it again and again turns out it is the drum that is not properly aligned within its brackets.I bought this to replace a Lexmark 250dn that I have had for 10 years. But disappointed with the issues in this new machine. Sending it back.

title: Easy set up, but non-business user friendly 250 sheet tray + dumb controls to control feed trays
body: I have used a B&W laser printer for my daily work for about 15 years now. This is probably my fourth or fifth I've used during that time.There are five issues that are paramount: Ease of setup, ease of use, cost of use, features, and reliability/longevity of the printer.For ease of setup this Lexmark was as good or better than any other printer I've used. I had this up and running in minutes. Very easy. So far everything has seemed fairly intuitive. So five stars for setup.Ease of use was a different matter. I've had two big issues with this printer.One, the printer requires you to go into the controls to switch between the feed tray and the manual feeder. In my business I print packing lists on a full sheet and postage labels on a half sheet. The former uses the regular tray, the latter the manual tray. On all other printers I've used the printer has automatically switched between the two based on whether or not there was paper in the manual tray. If no paper was in the manual tray the printer goes to the regular tray. This printer doesn't do that. You have to switch back and forth using the controls and this is a major hassle. What were they thinking?!This printer also lacks a major feature. This model comes with a 250 sheet tray. I’m baffled and disgusted by this. Serious users buy reams of paper - a ream is 500 sheets. I see this flaw as a major detraction for anyone wanting to use this printer in a small office setting. I don’t want to have to keep filling the sheet tray. Making matters worse, it looks as if buying a 500 sheet tray costs over $100. Really not acceptable for a B&W laser printer that is clearly meant for daily use.Cost of use: I can’t really comment on this at this time other than to say the Lexmark branded toner cartridges seem to be on par with other brands. Don’t know yet about the price of off-brand toner.The one major positive in this category is the longevity of the drum/imager. Lexmark claims that it will last up to 60,000 pages which is a lot higher than the Brother laser printer I was using. Brother has a real scam going on with at least some of their current laser printers as their drums need replacing after perhaps 10,000 to 20,000 pages. Two drum replacements and you’ve basically spent the same amount as buying a new printer. Ridiculous. So if Lexmark’s claim is true this is a major positive.As for reliability, I obviously can’t really comment on that. I’ve found that modern printers are total junk in this category compared to just 10 years ago. Manufacturers are making printers to fail early. However, Lexmark’s claim of 60,000 pages for replacing the imaging unit gives me high hopes for this model. Crossing fingers.I’m giving this printer 5 stars for ease of use and the imaging unit replacement estimate. I’m giving it 2 stars for the horrible 250 sheet tray and the dumb user interface requiring the use to go into the to controls to switch between the feed trays. So 3 stars overall.

title: Works well hardwired. Wireless? Not so much.
body: Writing this is almost as complex as connecting this printer to my network.  I followed the directions and used the printer’s menu to connect the printer to my wireless network. I was able to go through the entire setup successfully but when I completed the process the display showed it’s IP address as 0.0.0.0 “Not Connected”. The printer would not connect to my wireless network.  I went through this setup five times, slightly more frustrated but also insecure, and each time it would find my network and allow me to input the password to connect.  After an hour or so I decided to take it to my office where it’s less likely to become a nap spot for the cat and I hardwired it to my network.  From there I was able to connect. At last.               The first thing I did was to log into the Web Service and try again to set up the wireless.  I noticed that all the information I had entered from the printer was already in Network settings.  Seeing that it was all there and correct, I unplugged the network cable to connect via wireless.  No connection.  The display on the printer said “Not Connected” and the IP address was 0.0.0.0. I won’t tell you what I said.               After an appropriate amount of cursing I plugged the wire back in and logged back into the printer to go through the wireless set up again.  Even after setting the printer with a Static IP address, one that I chose myself, I was still unable to connect via wireless.  So I shut it down and went to do something else. Like kick the cat through a fan. Or set fire to Alexa.               The next morning, fortified by a night’s sleep, a shower and a cup of Sumatra coffee, I fired everything back up. I was hopeful. I felt optimism and strength. But still it wouldn’t connect via wireless.  I connected the cable and  logged back in to  double check my settings.  I only changed the IP address to the next number in line from the wired connection.  I pulled the network cable and muttered an old limerick under my breath. That did it. it was able to connect via wireless.  I’m still not sure what the issue was since the only thing different that morning was a new IP address, everything else remained the same. But I don’t question why when the good *or* bad happens.               So now that I was connected via wireless I decided to run a few tests.  My first print test was a single page and I was impressed with the speed of the print job.  It was much faster than I expected for a printer this size.  So I decided to do a 12 page document and time it.  My first attempt errored out when the printer wouldn’t wake up to the print request.  So I cancelled the job, rebooted, and tried again.  As I waited I spilled coffee on my shirt and blamed the Lexmark, whom I have since begun to call Lex, suggesting various warm places it could go if it didn’t work. This time it accepted the job. After 1:40:74 minutes my twelve page, double sided print job was done.  But I noticed that after printing a page front and back it would pause for ten to twelve seconds before kicking out the next double sided page. It repeated this behavior until all six pages were done. But they were done. It was nearly 11:00am.               Another coffee. A clean shirt. I chose to connect with the cable and time the same print job. This time is printed 4 pages and then paused for 15-20 seconds before kicking out the last 2 pages.  Still it was much faster at 54:89 seconds.  This time the pause was long enough to give me concern that the print job had crashed. I was rather pessimistic by this time. But finally out it came.               After that I thought to do another print test but this time I would use my five year old, Brother HL-2270DW laser printer to compare the speeds. I was able to print the twelve page, double sided document in 1:17:04 minutes via wireless connection with no pause between pages. I took some time away from all of it and wrote a song about Mesopotamian farmers.               Over the course of many days I have been using this Lexmark for all of my print jobs.  Yesterday alone I printed a total of 37 pages in 10 jobs.  More than once the printer would pause between pages. Oddly it wasn’t consistent; sometimes it paused after one page print; sometimes it was after two or three pages.  The first page always slides out quickly, like an ATM dispenser in a dark alley. But after an encouraging start it became a crap shoot.  The pause was not the same every time either.  On one print of just two pages the pause was close to a minute and I got up, crossed the room- this time with a rubber mallet and clenched jaw- thinking the printer had crashed. Just as I reached it it blipped, burped and resumed.               My next test was to try everything on the wired connection. Feeling more confident, even thinking I could get used to the Lexmark, I plugged the cable in, switching it over to Wire Connection with a good IP address on the printer display.  I hit “print”. Nothing. It. wouldn’t. print.  I sincerely considered eating one of my wife’s Xanax and putting out a yoga mat with “Dark Side of the Moon.” Instead I did a breathing thing I use for singing warm-ups. The Lexmark print que listed the job but it was waiting for the printer to accept it.  It never did.  I had to power the printer down and reboot it for the wired connection to work properly.  Once connected, I retried my print jobs and there was no connection issues or a pause between pages.  A 25 page print job went through quickly and cleanly. I swear there were tears in my eyes. I even rubbed the cat and sang a little Sondheim. I waited a few weeks to write this, feeling that my initial relationship with Lex (a name I stumbled onto hoping for a more congenial relationship) might cause me to pepper this review with various words that would offend or, at the very least, tarnish my reputation here on Vine. So this review is written with a staid and honest attitude. And not because I took one of my wife’s pills.               Dealing with the toner was very easy and I can see that when the time comes to replace it that will go smoothly.  Over all it seems to be well made and sturdy; nothing flimsy.  I also like the second paper feed that allows me to change paper type without emptying the drawer.  My Brother Printer does not have this feature and it would have been nice to have a few times over the years.               I suspect that there is a defect in this unit, most likely in the wireless card. That’s the only reasonable explanation for the issues I’ve had. I suggest asking questions about this issue to the manufacturer and to others who own this model. When it’s hardwired to my network I find it to be a nice printer that would work well for home or small business.  Truthfully, if I had purchased this I would return it as defective and accepted another unit to replace it.  If that one worked I would keep it and be a very satisfied customer. If it didn’t I think I’d self commit to a psychiatric hospital. With the cat.

title: Great quality and amazingly easy setup make this a great buy
body: The printing quality is very high and looks great, but to me the most important part of a printer is ease of use considering how much of a pain they often are. This printer was extremely easy to setup and to start printing (even over wifi), it comes with an app that you download on your phone to configure it and I had it up and printing within about 10 minutes of opening the box. It is a tad bulky but it looks quite nice and prints quickly. Definitely 5 stars based mostly on the ease of use alone.

title: Speed and quality of prints is great!
body: This is a great printer. The cost is very reasonable for a quality Laser printer like this. It takes up a modicum of space in my home office and turns out wonderful prints on not only quality paper, but on photo paper which I use quite extensively.This is a fast printer and will produce prints in a flash when you have to make a bunch of them at the same time. We use this for my students and they appreciate that when there are handouts we can provide them each week for different subjects being studied.Have not had to change printer cartridges as yet, but the instructions make this very easy to do.

title: love this color laser printer, should've ditched my inkjet years ago
body: This printer is amazing for the price - it's on screen controls are a bit basic, and it's not a color screen but it has everything you need really. You can easily go to the devices webpage and configure all the defaults and more detailed aspects of it. It was easy enough to set up on the network, and I didn't even use the driver disc to install it on my computers, everything works fine using the windows 10 default drivers and if you have a mac/ipad then they find it perfectly using airprint. My only concern is how long the toner lasts - hopefully as long as they claim (1000 pages, i think?) because they are pretty pricey. We are infrequent printers in my house, so 1000 pages of printing before toner runs out would basically last us years. It's definitely nice not having to worry about inkjet ink running out after only 50 pages or so (or exactly when your kids have a project they have to print) or streaking or any of the other problems that I have with my inkjet. I was also pleasantly surprised to find it can print double sided, since I didn't notice duplexing listed as a feature. I really should have gotten one a long time ago and quit messing with inkjets altogether, since the new color lasers really aren't that much more than a decent inkjet printer and print way faster and better.

title: Setup is awful and the printer is persnickety
body: I've had a brother color laser for many years. It stopped recognizing magenta cartridges so it was time for a new printer. I put the C2325dw is the same spot as our old Brother printer. Same AC plugin, same Network cable. The new Lexmark acted very flaky. It refused to stay connected. It refused to play with the Lexmark App on my phone when in Wifi Setup mode. I ended up having to update the firmware - which appeared to be old.After updating the firmware and changing out power and network cables it seems to be working a little better. My fingers are crossed that one of these things really fixed the problem.The printer is persnickety about how the paper is placed in the tray. The tray has the paper in at a angle rather then square. With my brother printer, you just adjusted the guides and there were no issues. The Lexmark the paper slides and it's feeder seems to care. It took a few tries to get the paper to feed out of the tray without error. I think have the hang of it now, but the infographic setup that was in the box was not of any help with this issue.The print quality seems pretty good - except for that line the runs down middle of the page when printing color prints. It's okay for regular printing, but for photos it really shows. Perhaps as it is broken in and run for a bit, this will improve.The reason I had a Brother printer orignally is that the consumables are cheap. You can buy 3rd party toner for peanuts. This printer the toner appears to be $60-$80 per color. With the Brother I could get toner for all the colors and two for black for that price. I'm hoping the printer came with high capacity cartridges because - yikes.Given the pain needed to get the printer up - I think I'm being generous giving it 3 stars. My fingers are crossed that the printer turns out better than it's first impression.

title: Much better than my 3 year old HP laserjet
body: I got this to replace my 3 year old HP Laserjet printer. This for one thing is a pretty nice machine. The thing right out of the box looks great. The install was another story. I don't know why, but printers in our home has always been a struggle. They are always difficult. This was a little tricky to get set up and install. I had some trouble getting it onto my network. The process took a little over 30 minutes to get everything up and going and talking to one another. After the install, I was impressed at how nice this is. The printer makes clean crisp copies and prints pretty fast too. The most challenging part was setting up, if you can get it all installed ok, then I would highly recommend this printer. Looks and works great.

title: Good quality printing
body: I received this printer to review as part of the Amazon Vine program. Below are my pros/cons.Pros:- Very good quality printing (easily better than my old inkjet printer).- Prints pages quickly; when printing single-sided, this baby can really spit the printed pages out.- Comes with duplex included (both-sided printing).- It's smooth; it doesn't shake "back-and-forth" like my old ink-jet printer did when printing.- Seems designed to be largely idiot-proof, and I'm the idiot testing it.Cons:- Instructions were a single sheet with several large diagrams; I followed the items and was able to get the printer up and running. NOTE - install the printer drivers using the supplied disk, not by searching the internet. Also note that you do have an option to download stuff to your cell phone, but I'm old school and prefer to have an instruction manual included and in front of me.- The printer did not print "duplex" right out of the box. Here is where the lack of a printed manual with a "troubleshooting" section was sorely felt. I had to go online, where I found a solution: "confirm that the paper type selected on your printer corresponds to the media actually loaded into the printer. Do this through the printer driver (Paper tab) as well as the printer operator panel (Paper Menu). IMPORTANT: Labels and transparencies will print on one side of the page only (simplex) regardless of the printer or driver settings. If the media type is set to Labels or Transparency, change the setting to allow for duplex printing."- The printer jammed a lot and often grabbed more than one sheet of paper. I'm hoping this will lessen, as I get used to this printer's idiosyncrasies.Things worth noting (neither a pro nor a con):- This is advertised as a single function printer, and it is ... single function means no copying or scanning ... all it does is print. Read the manufacturer provided info carefully.- While the printer isn't overly large, it is heavy ... around 50 pounds.- It has a paper cassette tray, and there is a slot where you can feed letters, envelopes, and transparencies in manually.Overall, I like this printer, and am looking forward to getting a lot of use out of it. If you can afford it, the time to shift to color laser printers has arrived. Four stars.

title: Incredibly frustrating setup, but good print quality. No network security.
body: I'm rating this based on how it works as a printer, not according to the incredibly frustrating setup. If I'm rating the installation experience, I'd have given it at most 2 stars - and only because I managed to figure it out in the end through experimentation and trial and error.Instead of describing my arduous installation experience, I'm just going to give a list of tips of what you should do.1. I wanted to use this over WiFi. If you can use it over wired Ethernet, it might be much simpler.2. I tried to configure it with the front panel. If you have a long WiFi password, please reconsider. I entered it anyway, taking 5 minutes to enter it, and it wouldn't connect to my WiFi.3. I'm using an Android phone. The Lexmark Mobile Assistant only configures the WiFi settings. It will ask you to connect to the printer's WiFi through Settings.4. If you see a warning message on Android saying there's no Internet connection after you're connected to it, and to tap on it for options, TAP ON IT FOR OPTIONS. Accept that it has no Internet connection. I didn't do that, and as a result, the Mobile Assistant would not go on to the next step.5. After you've configured WiFi, the printer may kick you back to pick language, and ask if you want to use Mobile Assistant for setup again. If it does that, reply NO. Then, when it comes to the screen where it asks you if you want to configure WiFi, say NO. It will then say "Connected".Getting to step 5 above took me 2 hours of trial and error and multiple restarts.6. Check to see if you need a firmware update. Lexmark's website has a good description of how to update firmware. The C2325dw does not have a USB A port at the back, so you need to do either FTP or through the internal web server.7. The web server is a much more user friendly procedure, but it wouldn't complete for me. The printer showed a CRC error after 45%, and eventually rebooted. If it works for you, skip step 8.8. I updated it with Windows FTP client. If Windows prompt you to give it firewall permission, grant it. The instructions did not tell you to first put the client in binary transfer mode. So instead of just "PUT <filename>", I first issued "BIN", then "HASH" (optional, to show hash marks as it's uploading so that I know it's still transferring) then finally "PUT <filename>". This worked. Printer rebooted and showed new firmware.9. To install Windows drivers, I just downloaded and ran "Lexmark Printer Software G2 Driver and Software". I ignored "Lexmark Printer Software G2 Postscript Driver Package" since the first one is much larger and includes Postscript support.10. Running it the first time, it couldn't detect the printer, and became unresponsive. I killed the task, then ran it again. Second time it detected the printer immediately.I hope the above was helpful. Maybe printers with newer versions of firmware (mine was 050 something) will be more stable.The printer itself is very heavy. I didn't weigh it, but Lexmark says it weighs 45 lbs and that seems about right. Unpacking it, you need to open up 2 compartments and pull out some straps that stabilize the internal parts during shipping before plugging it in. It looks a bit simple, and the plastic walls seem a bit thin, but frankly it's quite amazing for a color laser printer that costs under $300.The back of the printer has a USB Type B and Ethernet port. No USB or Ethernet cables are supplied so if you want to use one of these ports, you need to provide your own cable. USB Type B is the one with a large-ish square connector typically only used in printers.There's a paper tray and you can adjust it for different paper size. Mine was set just a little too small for Letter, so I was a bit puzzled when I put paper in and it didn't quite fit. Adjusting it is pretty straightforward.Configuring it through the two line LCD is quite tedious. It's much easier doing it through the web interface. One thing that concerns me is that neither the web interface nor the FTP interface has any security, and it's not obvious to me if there's any way to add even a simple password to protect it. Make sure the network you're connecting it to is secure, and it's a good idea to turn it off when you're done printing.Once everything is set up, printing it is very straightforward. I haven't printed many pages through it yet, but so far printing is smooth and fast, and print quality is good. Text is crisp and I look forward to not having to pay for expensive ink cartridges. I'm not sure why the magenta toner shows as 2/3 full before I printed a single page though (see photo).I will keep this review updated based on my experience. I thought I'd get this out first so that the installation tips can help some people.

title: Awesome!
body: Super easy to setup!Instructions for removing certain plastic pieces used for shipping were easy to follow. The instructions provided pictures for each step.Had no problems setting up on my 2.4Ghz password protected WiFi network.I was able to setup without using the included CD or the mobile app they recommend. I downloaded drivers from Lexmark’s website. I have them installed on a Debian Linux distribution, an OpenMediaVault (CUPS) distribution, and on a Windows 7 virtual machine. Each method I got working first try w/o any software bloat. Very happy with setup.The physical size is pretty large…. Compared to my Canon MF4890dw.. (see pic). I assume a lot of the increase in size is due to it being a color laser and needing multiple toner cartridges. I am impressed with the build quality of the Lexmark, each tray, slider, handle, etc… are all pretty thick and rigid plasticPrint quality meets expectations… hard to describe in words, but perfect for all document type of printing. Don’t expect photocenter quality prints or anything.Scanning quality is superb… and I haven’t even used the highest quality setting yet. 200 DPI is providing excellent results, both grayscale and color. I’ve had some problems scanning in very thin paper into the document feeder, it wants to grab multiple pages at once. I have not had any problem scanning in standard weight paper through the feeder. Has a nice feature when you initiate a scan from a PC, there is an option to either scan immediately, or wait until you select a menu option from the printer. Good feature if the printer is not immediately next to you.Overall, highly recommended this printer. So far the only problem was scanning in the thin paper through the feeder, but I don’t really blame the printer as I even had problems separating the paper with my own hands.

title: Good Multi-Function Printer
body: The physical set up was easy - pretty much on-par with the Epson Multifunction Inkjet that it is replacing. I have it set up on WiFi for now, and expect to directly plug it in to Ethernet when I move it (WiFi was the more complex set-up, and it wasn't a problem). Full color double-sided prints on legal sized paper came out sharp and clean! Setting up the scan-to-email functions do appear a little harder, but I am not sure if that is the printer or Google. I haven't gotten that quite working yet. The duplex sheet-feeder works nicely. It seems to be able to handle a mix of paper types, though I did note that it can't handle duplex on 80-lb paper, and when there is a mix of 20-lb, 40-lb, and 60-lb paper, it seems to jam on duplexing the 60-lb paper, otherwise, seems to work fine. Overall, it seems to work wonderfully!

title: Full-featured color printer
body: The MC2425adw is a great choice for a small office, home, or a workgroup. It feels very sturdy and well-made and has an abundance of features.This all-in-one prints at up to 25ppm, and is rated for a monthly print volume of up to 6,500 pages, so it should be up to the demands of most small offices. In testing, it reached (or at least came pretty close) to the 25ppm. I had no desire to burn through 15 or so reams of paper though, so I can't vouch for the monthly volume rating. Print quality was outstanding and it presented no problems using AirPrint from an iPhone or iPad. Setup was a breeze (with Macs, anyway; we don't have any Windows PCs), both wireless and using Ethernet. The instructions are clear and relatively concise. The Macs just found the printer and automatically installed the driver. If you have any experience setting up printers, this will be non-event. Even if you are a novice, you should be able to follow the instructions without much trouble. There might be some benefit to downloading the latest and greatest driver from the Lexmark website, but in my experience, the one Apple has worked just fine.The MC2425adw prints its first page quickly, too, usually spitting out the first page 12-14 seconds after hitting, "print," not bad for a consumer-oriented color printer.While great as a home or small-office machine, it has a couple of features that make it very comelling for office use. The first is the ability to print securely. If you select this option in the print job dialog, your job won't print until you go to the printer and enter a PIN you selected when printing. This is very useful to ensure that sensivive documents don't print until you are physically at the printer waiting for them. This is a nice feature in any office, and indispensable in confidential environments such as medical and legal offices.The second is the ability to add an additional, 650-page capacity, duo input tray. From the description, this optional tray is a 550-page additonal input tray + a 100-page multi-purpose feeder. I don't have this tray, but it looks to be very useful if you regularly print from a variety of page types/sizes. The built-in tray holds 250 sheets, plus there is the usual multi-purpose feeder. The addition of an extra input tray can either give you access to an additional paper size/type, or just add extra capacity of a single size so you don't have to refill as often. Having the ability to load 800+ sheets of paper at once would be great in an office with a heavy print volume.There are a couple of things that are less than ideal, however. The first is this cryptic note in the "Specs" section on the Lexmark website: "Product functions only with replacement cartridges designed for use in a specific geographical region." This appears to mean that replacement cartridges are locked to a specific region, sort of like DVDs; I've personally never heard of this and am just speculating. That may or may not be an issue, but is something you should be aware of.The second is that, while the printer is well-suited for a moderate to heavy burden of office printing, the scanner and copier are less so if you are scanning or copying duplex documents. It scans duplex, to be sure. However, it does this by way of RADF (Reversing Automatic Document Feeder). This means that it scans one side of the page, ejects that page not quite all the way, then re-feeds it to scan the other side. Essentially, it takes twice as long to scan a 2-sided document as it does a single-sided one. The ideal scanners and copiers have true Duplex Automatic Document Feeders (DADF), with two scanning elements so that both sides of the page are scanned during a single pass. This is not an issue unless you have a heavy scanning or copying volume, AND a great percentage of that volume consists of documents printed on both sides. The ADF holds 50 pages.The all-in-one also sends and receives faxes, but I only have a VOIP landline, so I couldn't test any fax functions. This machine, like literally every other one I have ever owned or tested (which is 7 or so over the last 10 years), just doesn't work with a VOIP line for some reason.The price of this printer is quite reasonable for the quality and capabilities you get. Overall, this is a great all-in-one. I would have no hesitation making this my primary machine in either my office or home.

title: Solidly Built. Good Performance.
body: I received this printer in November and have been printing with it for several weeks now.I have been testing the different features of it on a MacBook Pro and iPhone X.I have always considered Lexmark to manufacture professional printers since I saw a lot of them being used in graphic design offices. My friends who worked there always praised them.I appreciate the opportunity to review this Color Laser on one end, yet I now know that I am a new toner cartridge customer from now on out if I continue to use it.This MC2425adw arrived in a large cardboard box with nylon straps around it and plenty of internal packaging. It was very well packaged. It is a heavy printer with the package weighing in at around 67 lbs. It had to be well packaged. My first thought upon seeing the box on my doorstep was how big and heavy duty the box was.I'm running MacOS 10.14.1 which has the drivers for this Lexmark already installed. It is still a good idea to go to Lexmark's website to check for firmware or driver updates. It is also a good time to register the printer if you want to do that. The latest update is a "combined print scan fax driver for 10.6.8 and later MacOS". It was released on 6-15-2018.Lexmark is a little behind on their pull down menu system for driver selection as 10.13 was the latest choice in the menu. They need to get 10.14 listed. Anyways, this driver works.I found the scanner works best with the Apple "Preview" app. You can choose the MC2325 as your source to scan from the flatbed or feeder. Scans turn out nice. The warmup and processing speeds are fast.The fax function works fine if you have a traditional landline phone. VOIP may or may not work very well. I have found it to be problematic with other fax machines and multifunction printers as well. It is the sending that can be problematic. It receives faxes just fine over VOIP.Copy functions are fine. You can copy in color or B&W. Letter size.Now to the laser printing. The first thing I noticed is how quickly it warms up and begins the printing job. It is faster than older color lasers that I have used. It isn't any louder than the Canon we have in our office right now. It is average in noise level. Not any louder to me. The print quality is very good. Lexmark toner produces vibrant colors and a broad range of color too. The 2400 x 600 dpi produces crisp text and sharp graphics. I think it has a terrific resolution. It outputs around 25ppm and has duplex printing. The starter color toner cartridges that come with the printer are said to print about 750 pages and the starter B&W around 1,400 pages..You get in the box:-the printer-starter toner cartridges-Lexmark Cartridge Collection Program information sheet- warranty card-setup guilde- a power cord- CD software and electronic owners manualIt supports media sizes:A6, Oficio, 7 3/4 Envelope, 9 Envelope, JIS-B5, A4, Legal, A5, Hagaki Card, Letter, B5 Envelope, C5 Envelope, Executive, Universal, DL Envelope, Folio, 10 Envelope.It has these paper handling abilities: Integrated Duplex, Single-Sheet Manual Feed, 150 Sheet capacity output bin, 250 sheet capacity input bin.It has these ports: Gigabit Ethernet (10/100/1000), Front USB 2.0, 802.11b/g/nOverall I have to say this is a very good printer. I have been getting excellent results with it printing from a MacBook Pro as well as from an iPhone. I like it a lot and think it deserves a full 5 stars.

title: Serious small group color laser
body: First, it suits my needs for a task group shared printer. Keep the box and packing if your requirements include shipping off-site.Install is typical which is to say it takes about an hour to get the printer and linked computers set-up. Wireless connectivity is a snap. The full fidelity color laser output on a standard stock paper is primo for marketing and proposal quality production. 800-page drawer capacity is an instant labor cost saving.Note the size and weight to ensure or prepare your planned placement.If you are used to setting up and using this class printer with ink or laser, there won't likely be a problem for you.For gloss photo quality production, I prefer ink. Laser quality photo quality really does require the special laser gloss stock which I've not tried on this printer and likely won't ... deferring to inkjet.Bottom line:The Lexmark 2425 is the latest and greatest in small group laser printing. I love it so far. The transition to full laptop/desktop printer control has advanced and means no intermediate steps to the printer.5-star ... Better than advertised. This is a fantastic printer at a value for money price.

title: Lexmark MC2425adw
body: I have this printer alongside a comparable HP, model MFPM477fdw and I can say that running them side by side, the color output is indistinguishable. The Lexmark is quite a bit larger in size. The Lexmark cartridges are different than your typical HP and cost a bit more. My local toner guy says he can refill them so I'm not concerned. I can't comment on the yield as I'm still on the starter cartridges that were included. The Lexmark has all the features you come to expect in a desktop color laser these days. You can insert a USB drive and print directly from the divide without computer intervention. It's easy to set up and put into service. I like the fact that it has more actual buttons instead of a 100% touch screen like the HP. This is a robust small office printer that will handle your printing requirements at an attractive price. If you are shopping for a multi function color laser, this is worth a hard look.

title: Laser over ink.
body: I've owned a laser printer for over a year now, and have to say I will never go back to ink. I went through a variety of printer brands and models, and all of them lasted about a year before performance issues began to creep up. Then at around the two year mark they would just fail completely (mostly ugly horizontal streaks that I couldn't calibrate away). That alone was worth switching, but I also hated being constantly told to buy more ink when I had plenty (my HP would go months printing before it "actually" ran out), and also the monthly calibration/cleaning cycles. So far with my laser printer: zero hassle.Now for this model exactly: This printer was intimidating to set up at first, but after a few Google searches was able to finish. Once done, I was able to print, scan, and copy with no issues. Quality of printing is fantastic. So far very pleased, but will be returning to adjust score in the future if anything should crop up.

title: Only shortcoming is the documentation.
body: I would have given this printer 5 stars if it were not for the sometimes confusing documentation. I've had it for 5 days but had it connected to my WiFi and printing from several computers within a few hours. Over the weekend I kept puzzling over using the scanner to scan a document into my PC. The User's Manual only refers to accessing "scan profiles" from the menu but there is no scan profile in the Web Server menu or the front panel menu. Finally, I discovered that I could simply use Windows Fax and Scan to do it but I still plan on calling Lexmark support to clarify the User Manual's instructions. What I suspect is, is that they have tried to write one user manual to cover about a dozen different models and things got so abstract that it's not very useful. But that aside, it looks like a great printer/scanner/copier. Still don't really understand how the toner exchange program works but that will come.

title: Will the warranty pay for service and who do I call.
body: We bought two of these and are having trouble with both of them with paper jams.We need service on them. Will the warranty pay for service. And who do I call.

title: Tech support needs help.
body: Would have given it a 5 but I had a problem with the wireless and called tech support and they had to escalate it to next level. Never heard back from them. I had it replaced and is working perfectly

title: It's ok
body: It work, but not very clear instructions. Scanning doesn't seem to be able to do in adobe format. I called tech support, but found a google search to be more informative than the support line. The support line does not seem to know their own products or basic scanning formats at all. Price was decent and it works REALLY fast which is nice.

title: Better than inkjet!
body: Had a few issues installing the software, mainly for scanning. But works great!

title: Not for business use
body: I purchased to replace a Xerox Mfc that was still working fine just old. I work in the IT business so I know what to look for. I read all specs and reviews and reviewed specs on Lexmark's site. Printing is good and speed is good. They claim network scanning ability but that does not work. You can scan over a network to your computer but you cannot scan to a network folder. Also you have to initiate the scan from you computer, not good if you have several documents to scan. Also does not scan to PDF and if scanning a multipage document it creates a jpg file for each page. Tiff & PNG is not acceptable file format in business where everyone has a PDF reader.Probably should have sent the unit back

title: Multi function printer does not scan
body: The lack of help line is also horrible. I have spent about 1.5 hours total on the line. This printer is supposed to scan, but they have not been able to figure out how to do that. No icon is on the computer screen to control the printer. Unless things Improve I will return this piece of junk.

title: Fast and great print quality
body: I love this printer. It is easy to set up, including connecting it to my WiFi network. To connect, I could do it from the machine itself without loading software and hardwiring it to a computer to start. The machine is fast to respond and to print, and produced really nice text and pictures, including auto duplexing. I compared the test to an HP laser printer (B&W that one) and the test from the Lexmark is finer and less course. There is a manual feed slot at the bottom of the printer to use for envelopes, or other custom paper if desired. I had to play with my envelope layout, but now it is easy to print envelopes too, even from my phone, since the printer has AirPrint. .I tried printing a photo and it looked great on letter paper. Compared to one printed professionally (photo paper), it was a bit more red and less nuanced, but the Lexmark certainly did a better job than I had expected.I haven't tried scanning yet, but the copy function, both doc feeder and flat bed, produce nice copies.Note the size of the printer though. The footprint is on the large side.

title: Toner breaks the bank and difficult to setup.
body: They should give you the printer. It costs $500 every 3,500 copies for toner. No compatible options.For setting up the WiFi, you are asked to download the LexMark app. The App can't be started because there is no way to accept the terms and conditions. The other option is to setup via the keypad. There is no indication where the space character is. I called Bangladesh for tech support and after 30 minutes of trying to explain what the space character is, I figured it out on my own.

title: Disappointed!!
body: Had it for less than a month and maybe 50 pages printed on it and the fuser is bad. Cheaper to buy a whole new unit than a replacement fuser

title: You get what you pay for
body: Dirtied every page printed and left streaks. Completely unusable.

title: Excellent Printer- Loaded with High End Features
body: This printer packs a punch with all of its loaded features. It's hard to find a high-quality printer with all of the features this printer and 'all in one' offers. No more trips to the copy store for color duplex projects. Excellent quality output for high resolutions jobs, and adjustable resolution for day to day printing, duplex scanning, and our faxing needs.It's a larger size printer, more height than width. Setting up was a breeze. I highly recommend this printer.

title: Love it
body: Love it, it was well worth the money

title: Three defective printers in 2 weeks
body: Had to return the product 3 times, simpk y stopped working and customer support was unable to help

title: No - Just No
body: I'll admit setup wasn't hard. That's the only good thing about it. After one week it broke. We brought it in to be fixed because dealing with the warranty was a hassle. Two weeks later, it broke again. Again, we had it repaired because support is useless. When it broke for the third time, I'd had enough. Doesn't matter what it's capable of doing if it won't last long enough to actually do it. Lexmark is usually a great brand. Look for a different model if you want one of their color laser models because something is really wrong with this one.

title: Lot of bang for the buck!
body: Cannot believe how well this machine works for the price we paid. We'll see how the longevity works out, but we are super happy with product for its cost!!

title: You get what you pay for
body: Inexpensive Color Laser, good print quality, construction not so much, I will be shocked it this printer lasts me more than a couple of years, the feeding mechanism is really noisy out of the box, sounds like one that already has 10,000 pages through it not 10. I would recommend spending a little more money and upgrade from this unit.

title: Broken in less than 3 weeks, terrible customer support
body: After clearing out a paper jam the error message won't go away. I did all the troubleshooting I could then called support. I had to provide my name, address, proof a purchase, and serial number then was told my case would be sent to the back room for approval. A week later I've heard nothing. if I had kept the box I'd return it. Waste of money and time. Buy Brother. I'd give this 1 star if I could.

title: Bad out of the box
body: The printer may be the best but i couldn't tell you as it was junk out of the box.Contacted customer service and got lots of promises but no action. Pick another brand.Well another day has gone by with Nothing from lexmark.

username: Leah Maines, best-selling, award-winning author, actor, and editor
title: Very good quality
body: I have owned many, many printers. The Lexmark Color Laser Printer is a very good printer. It’s bigger than I expected, but not so big as to be a problem. The print quality is very good. It’s very easy to set up. Really, you just take it out of the box and plug it in. My computer found it right away. It is easy to use. The paper tray holds a lot of paper. I’m a fan of Lexmark printers. This is my second or third Lexmark, and I really like them better than my Brother or HP printers. Overall, this is a great printer for the price.

title: Horrible tools. "Virtual Solution Center" is a cruel joke.
body: Unless you are a corporate system administrator who is MS certified, do not buy this printer. There is no way to manage the printer or update firmware. Lexmark ostensibly does this through the "Virtual Solution Center." It requires a plugin for the browser to work. Simple enough, right? No so quick. After the plugin installs, it does not run. Hmmm. I check browser setting and modify one per the instructions. Still doesn't work. Now the troubleshooting has me going into system32 files to make mods. I try that... opps. I don't have permission. So now I am working on changing permissions to system files and folder. What a hassle. Really!!! I'm a tech savvy person and ran the tech helpdesk for a Fortune 100 company, I still wasn't able to get it to work. I could call one of my former support agents and have him help me change all the settings on my new computer - but why should I? This printer is CLEARLY NOT intended for home use. it is too poorly supported. That is unfortunate because it seems to print fine, but there can be no support without the Virtual Solution. Why wouldn't Lexmark just provide an app like every manufacturer.... I have had Brother, Canon and HP printers and never had a problem. I think I will be sending this thing back.

title: Just buy it, you will like it.
body: Great features for the price. Works faster than my old printer.

title: Perfect Prints
body: This thing prints really fast, and dark. Way better than inkjet.

title: Love the WiFi feature
body: First printer didn’t work but they shipped a replacement. Second printer is fast.

title: Very good value, easy set up, superb printing quality.
body: We have a large commercial-grade Lexmark (laser) printer in our home office. My wife wanted one downstairs for her iMac, so we found this great deal. Easy setup, very fast and very network friendly (wireless). Replacement toner cartridges are pricey, but that goes with being a laser printer. Excellent buy.

title: Hard to install for Ipad Air Print
body: Purchased for Air Print feature to use with Ipads. One of Ipads couldn't accept the needed late version operating software. The newer Ipad I was unable to set up. I'm going to give it away since we cab't use it.

title: Great Printer
body: Great printer, easy to set up, prints on both sides.. I was able to set this up to print my chest since my old printer was malfunctioning. Very happy with product.

title: Incredibly fast printing, clean black and white pages, easy setup
body: I love this laser printer from Lexmark. It prints incredibly fast and the pages are perfect. Blacks are smooth and dark while the white page is clean and smudge free. Setup was almost a breeze. I did have trouble connecting to wifi but it eventually worked out. The printer does make a little grunt after each round of printing, but I'm assuming that's normal. I removed the drum and reseated it a few times without any difference in this response. Otherwise, everything works well.Ignore other reviews that say this printer can hold an extra large toner that prints 6000 pages. I have confirmed with Lexmark that this particular model, B2338adw, cannot use that cartridge. The standard cartridge prints up to 3000 pages which is excellent for most people. The included starter cartridge prints 1500 pages. Unfortunately, this printer doesn't seem to be able to hold generic toner cartridges so you are locked into the Lexmark cartridges and prices.I prefer this laser printer over my inkjet printer. I used to set my inkjet to print in grayscale only because the ink is expensive and I don't print photos or need color for personal use. My inkjet is now in the closet. I'm pleased with the performance of this printer and would recommend it to my own family and friends.

title: Stopped working after first cartridge change
body: I ordered the brand new ink cartridge with the printer. The first cartridge lasted 6mo., and when it ran dry, I put in the new cartridge. it is a Lexmark cartridge, it says it is for my printer, yet my printer says incompatible cartridge. Now it will not work. I updated the system, through it was just built in Sept of last year. So stupid. I hate printers. They are built to break.

username: Leah Maines, best-selling, award-winning author, actor, and editor
title: Good printer
body: The Lexmark Monochrome Laser Printer is a very good printer for the price. I have several printers, and I like the Lexmark brand. This printer prints only in black/grayscale. However, that is fine for most of my home office needs. It prints very fast. The print quality is good. The paper tray holds a fair amount of paper. It prints wirelessly with no problems. Setup is easy. I’m very happy with this printer

title: Fast, Good Print Quality, Easy to Hook Up, But Where's the Toner?
body: Let's be clear, it's a good printer. It was easy to set up, has decent features, and the print quality is good.Setup: cabled setup is easy, although if you're not going to go wireless, you'll have to supply your own cable, whether USB or Ethernet. I won't dock them for that, although they could have said "cable not supplied" in their writeups. This just worked out of the box on my Linux system. For Windows, you should probably download drivers from the Lexmark support site. Not sure about Mac.Wireless setup is accomplished from the little display window on the printer. I've always found this annoying but if you run Windows and want to install their software you can avoid this. But there is nothing hard about it, just a little tedium, and it works as it should, although I always prefer the Ethernet option. (Tip: on your router, assign a fixed IP address to the printer. This makes life easier for non-USB connections.)Okay, how does it work? Just fine. Double sided printing is wonderful, print quality is great, speed is about what you'd expect today--- in other words, very good for a home printer used by a few people. (Don't expect to use this in a 20 person office, though.) It's a light-duty printer, very suitable for a home office.Build quality is good. Don't drop it off tall buildings, but don't be afraid to move it around or carry it around. It should stand up just fine.Now, the one gripe. Toner. It comes with the plague of printers in pretty much the last decade, the dreaded "starter" cartridge. This is a cartridge that is maybe 10% full, meaning you have to buy a real cartridge almost right away. And guess what, the cartridge price is in the same range as the printer price in most cases. Manufacturers don't have to make money on the printer, they make it on the cartridge.The "starter" is supposed to be good for 500 pages, about one ream. If that holds up, depending on your needs, you might get a week or two in a busy home office, and maybe a month or two of really casual use.So you better order that cartridge. You go to the Lexmark site and ... oh my, they aren't selling them. Maybe a little later on? Better hope so, or pretty soon you'll have a brick. This is 100% inexcusable. And comparing similar Lexmark printers, the cartridge will be over a hundred dollars. Wow.Usually there are 3rd-party cartridges, often for about 15% of the price. That's what I always buy for my other printers; I find a reputable vendor and buy from them. But you cannot get the cartridge for this printer anywhere at the time of this writing (late March 2020).I'm going to provisionally rate the printer four stars. After all, it's a very good product. I would have gone five if the cartridges were available at a fair price. I will revisit this later. If in a month or two you still can't get the cartridge, the rating will be one star.

title: Fast print from cold start, easy to set up.  Clean print.  Needs documentation.
body: This is a very nice monochrome laser printer. One I had previously took a long time to print from a cold start. This one begins to print almost as quiickly as an inkjet printer. Print quality is excellent and print speed is high. Wireless setup was very quick and easy. I like Lexmark's Unison toner. It separates the toner cartridge and the imaging unit unlike other toner cartridges where the units are combined. The Unison toner cartridge doesn't need shaking to equalize printing and prints at lower temperature than previous types of toner, so that means lower energy costs as well as quicker printing from a cold start. My only issue is probably due to this being a new item that I received through the Amazon Vine program. There is no online documentation specific to this model and I have been unable to determine the toner replacement cartridge for this unit. I assume that will change once this is a fully supported printer. All things considered, this is a great printer. My older laser printer is now history.

title: Lexmark B3442dw Monochrome Laser Printer w/ Wireless, USB, Ethernet Capabilities, very nice printer
body: The Lexmark printer is a good solid made printer and has a nice small footprint. It does two-sided printing, and the monochrome laser printer is light, compact, and prints fast.Wireless set up was fairly easy. With the Wi-Fi makes one can print from mobile devices, as well as laptops or desktops. It also has USB and Ethernet connectivity available. It is capable of printing up to 42 pages per minute, I never printed that many pages at one time so I cannot validate that fact. It comes with a 1-GHz multi-core processor, 256 MB of memory, and 100-sheet multipurpose feeder, which is very convenient.I like this printer and can easily recommend it and give it a 5 stars rating.

title: Printer
body: The printer is a good size for small business; could even be used as a home printer, even though it’s monochrome, for simple print jobs or someone who isnt printing pictures or needs color. It was easy to setup connection to my wifi. I tried installing the software from the disk that was provided on a dell laptop with windows 10, 64 bit, however, it would begin the download process, but wouldn’t actually install on my computer. Once the initial download bar completed, nothing else happened. I looked in my downloads folder and other folders for the download, but nothing was there. I tried this multiple times and it didn’t work. Most companies will put the software on their website as well, but that wasn’t the case here. I was unable to find anything on the website. I couldn’t even find the specific printer/model on the site. So far, I am unable to fully test the product because the software will not install.

title: Office Quality
body: If you are looking for a nice printer for your home office, this one may be a good choice. First of all, this was simple to set up, even for someone who is still running Windows 7 Pro. I did use the disk to get rolling on the drivers - and it seemed to be updated drivers. The printer runs pretty quiet and quick. The biggest concern you may have is replacement toner cartridges, which similar printers at Lexmark are well over $100, although I haven't seen any for sale anywhere as of yet - but since this is a new product, I'm pretty sure they will roll out when the printer goes public. I'm not sure if this cartridge can be refilled - some offices I've worked in have had refillable cartridges, but I'd have to investigate more to see if that is possible for this one.

title: Super fast
body: I have been wanting just a monochrome printer for so very long, this is a dream. This arrived perfectly packaged and was very simple to get up and running. Important note...the enclosed instructions are not very helpful. We ended up googling assistance for getting our printer to print....and wer e happily directed to an app that set us up in less than a minute. Seems very odd that this wasn’t not put in or even on the box. That, along with how I can’t find any replacement toner cartridges...well...I hope Lexmark corrects that soon. This cartridge is supposed to be high yield so hopefully I won’t need the replacement soon.

title: Speedy monochrome for the small or home office
body: This compact laser printer (8 3/4" H x 14" W x 14" D) does just one thing, but it does it very well. From sleep to first page out is under 10 seconds and pages print at the advertised speed, even using the duplexer, which I love. The picture instructions are bad, and there is nothing else, but once you get the printer out of the box they kind of make sense. This does not come with any cables other than power, so if you want to connect other than wirelessly you will need an Ethernet cable to connect to your network or a printer cable (with that squarish connector) to connect to your computer. I opted for wireless as I wanted to test this with my Android tablet as well. Once you power on the printer you have to use the 2-line monochrome screen to set it up (date, time, time zone, connect to network). Not terrible, but a user manual would have made it much better. Do note that if you connect to a network it has to be 2G and not 5G. The driver for this is not on the Lexmark site as of this review, so I had to use the CD (I tried with the Windows driver and the pages printed like a negative, but the Lexmark software fixed that). The Lexmark app installed fine on my Android tablet (Samsung) and I was able to print from there as well. This is a no-frills B&W laser, but it is the best one I've ever used.

title: Very fast and works well. PC setup is easy. Mac setup is manual.
body: The first thing I noticed on setting up this new printer is that it came with only one page of pictorial setup info, and no manual. It did include a driver CD, but my iMac running Catalina couldn't find any files it could run on that. In addition, searching the Lexmark website found no useful information about this new B3442dw model (though I did find a brochure about its likely predecessor, the B2442dw.)Fortunately, I was easily able to set the printer up properly anyway. Just remove all the packing materials both around the toner cartridge and on the outside of the case, load some paper, and power the printer on. A built-in small display will talk you through the needed initial settings, including entering a password to join your WiFi network. From there it was simple to tell my iMac to add a printer, and chose that one from the bonjour list that appeared. Once set up, its Options & Supplies button in the driver allows all other settings to be seen and customized easily.Since I do also have a Windows 10 laptop PC (Dell Inspiron XPS 15), I WAS quickly and easily able to install a driver on that, using the included CD.Once a driver was installed, printing on both the iMac and the Dell was a simple matter of choosing the Lexmark printer for a document. The result was blazingly fast (I've never seen such quick duplex printing before), and good quality.Overall, this is an excellent printer, lacking only a bit more attention to documentation to be fully ready for prime time on Macs in addition to Windows PCs.Update: Just discovered an interesting problem. For no obvious reason, the link to this printer at IP address 192.168.1.26 has also taken over the link to my Western Digital MyCloudEx2Ultra at IP address 192.168.1.2. Attempting to open a Web page at 192.168.1.2 shows the printer's web page, the same as if I'd opened the page at 192.168.1.26. And the MyCloud can't be accessed unless the printer is powered off. Those two addresses should NOT be in conflict, but somehow are. I'll update once I figure it out.Update 2: No toner is listed as available yet for this printer, either here at Amazon or at the maker's website. Whether the toner for the earlier model B2442dw would also work on this new model is unknown. The printer comes with a starter toner.

title: Full Featured Networkable Printer
body: The printer does not seem to come with a USB cable. Same with the ethernet cable; if you want to connect this way, you’ll need to have an extra one on hand or buy one. Or at least mine didn’t come with any cables other than power. That was ok for me because I am using Ethernet and I have a bunch of spare Ethernet cables, and there is also wireless connectivity available. But USB likely the easiest way to get up and running for non-techies, so if this is you, have a spare printer cable lying around, or purchase one with the printer. Same with the ethernet cable; if you want to connect this way, you’ll need to have an extra one or buy one.Once unpacked and set up following the crude pictograms included, it was necessary to download the drivers and install them. The unit does come with a CD installer disk, but even if you have an antique computer with an optical drive, it makes more sense to go to the Lexmark website and download the latest drivers.
